doc.repnme: Transcript of oral history interview with William L. Bennett held on January 22, 1988
doc.abstracts: In January 1988, William L. Bennett was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by Robert W. Oliver. During his tenure at the Bank from 1949 to 1978, Mr. Bennett worked in the information and public affairs department as a financial editor. His transcript concerns his tenure at the Bank. He discusses Eugene Meyer as first president of the World Bank, his disagreement over the board of executive to run the day-to-day operations. Mr. Bennett elaborates on the bond ratings, the efforts made by John J. McCloy and his team to raise the visibility of the World Bank, and to establish its credibility as a lender. Finally, Bennett discusses George Woods recommending him to Robert McNamara resulting in his appointment as the representative to the World Bank in New York as financial relations advisor, and opines on the pros and cons of the International Development Association (IDA) setup within the World Bank.
